title: 103_s224
content: The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions under the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" allows the President to propose rescinding budget authority provided in an appropriations Act through a special message to Congress within 3 days of enactment. Once funds are made available for obligation, they cannot be proposed for rescission again under this Act. The "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993" permits the President to propose rescinding budget authority from an appropriation Act by sending special messages to Congress within 3 days of enactment. The special messages must include a draft bill or joint resolution for each item of budget authority to be rescinded and specify certain details outlined in section 1012(a). Additionally, procedures for expedited consideration are established. Procedures for expedited consideration are outlined in the "Enhanced Rescissions Act of 1993," requiring the majority or minority leader to introduce a draft bill or joint resolution within two days of receiving a special message from the President regarding rescinding budget authority. Failure to introduce the bill results in automatic introduction on the third day. On the third day after receiving a special message from the President, any Member of the House may introduce a bill or joint resolution regarding rescinding budget authority. The bill will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations, which must report it without substantive revision within seven days. The Committee on Appropriations must report a bill or joint resolution regarding rescinding budget authority within seven days of receiving a special message. If the committee fails to do so, they will be discharged from consideration, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for a vote within 10 days. The bill or joint resolution must be voted on in the House of Representatives or the Senate within 10 days of its introduction. If agreed to, it will be engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House of Congress. The bill or joint resolution must be transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day it is agreed to. It will be referred to the Committee on Appropriations without substantive revision and must be reported within seven days of continuous session. The bill or joint resolution must be reported within seven days of continuous session. Failure to do so will result in automatic discharge from consideration, and the bill or joint resolution will be placed on the calendar for a vote on final passage within 10 days. The bill or joint resolution must be reported within seven days of continuous session. If agreed to in the House, the engrossed bill or joint resolution will be returned to the originating House by the Clerk of the House of Representatives or the Secretary of the Senate. The engrossed bill or joint resolution must be reported within seven days of continuous session and returned to the originating House. A motion in the House of Representatives to proceed to the consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section is highly privileged and not debatable. Debate on a bill or joint resolution under this section in the House of Representatives shall not exceed 4 hours. Debate on a bill or joint resolution under this section in the House of Representatives shall not exceed 4 hours, divided equally between those favoring and opposing the bill. Appeals from decisions of the Chair regarding the Rules of the House of Representatives for bills under this section shall be decided without debate. The Rules of the House of Representatives apply to the procedure for bills or joint resolutions under this section, with decisions made without debate. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to consideration of a bill or joint resolution is privileged and not debatable, with no amendments allowed. Debate in the Senate on a bill or joint resolution under this section, and all debatable motions and appeals, shall not exceed 10 hours, equally divided between the majority leader and the minority leader. Amendments to the motion are not allowed, and reconsidering the vote is not in order. Debate in the Senate on any debatable motion or appeal in connection with a bill or joint resolution under this section is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the manager of the bill, controlled by the minority leader if the manager is in favor. The minority leader or designee can allot additional time to Senators during the consideration of a bill. A motion to further limit debate on a bill is not debatable, and no amendments are allowed for bills considered under this section. No amendments allowed for bills considered under this section. Amendments prohibited in both House of Representatives and Senate. Budget authority proposed for rescission must be available for obligation the day after defeat in either House. The term 'appropriation Act' includes general or special appropriation Acts, supplemental Acts, and continuing appropriations. The continuity of a session of Congress is only broken by an adjournment sine die. The continuity of a session of Congress is considered broken only by an adjournment sine die, excluding days when either House is not in session due to an adjournment of more than 3 days. If a special message is transmitted during a Congress and the last session adjourns before 10 calendar days of continuous session, the message is still valid. The message transmitted during a Congress is deemed to have been sent on the first day of the next Congress if the last session adjourns sine die. Rulemaking powers under Section 904 of the Act are amended to include sections 1013 and 1018. The text chunk discusses amendments to sections 1011 and 1015 of the Act, including changes to subsections and paragraph numbers. Amendments are made to section 1015 of the Act, including changes to subsections and paragraph numbers. Amendments to section 1015 of the Act include redesignating subparagraphs, changing numbers, and inserting new subparagraphs related to transmitting a special message for a proposed rescission under section 1013. Amendments to section 1016 of the Act involve redesignating sections and updating references to include section 1014 in addition to sections 1012 and 1013. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections to reflect these changes. "Sec. 1013. Expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions."
